questions.text: A 26-year-old man complains of burning pain when urinating. He reluctantly acknowledges that four days ago, he engaged in unprotected sexual activity. The following examination findings are seen. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria Gonorrhoeae

 

Option D:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae
 

  • The patient's symptoms, which appeared four days after unprotected sex, are consistent with urethritis brought on by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, whose incubation period is one to five days.
  • Male gonococcal infection most frequently manifests as acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge. Depending on the nature of the sexual contact, pharyngeal and rectal infections can also happen.
     
  • However, the urethra, rectum, and pharynx may also be affected. In women, the cervix is the primary site of infection.
     
  • Excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, profound dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, and intermenstrual bleeding are among the symptoms.
     
  • Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is most frequently brought on by Chlamydia, which has a 1–3-week incubation period.
    Typically, only dysuria is present, but mucopurulent discharge can also happen. NGU can also be brought on by Mycoplasma genitalium and Trichomonas vaginalis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chlamydia trachomatis:
 

  • It is also a common cause of urethritis, but it typically causes a less pronounced or even asymptomatic presentation compared to gonorrhea.

 

Option B. Mycoplasma genitalium:
 

  • It is another cause of urethritis but is less common than gonorrhea and chlamydia and often causes milder symptoms.

 

Option C. Trichomonas vaginalis:
 

  • This causes trichomoniasis which typically presents with a frothy discharge and is more commonly symptomatic in females than males.



Educational Objective:

 

  • When a male patient presents with purulent urethral discharge and reports recent unprotected sexual activity, the most likely diagnosis is gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Identification is typically confirmed through culture of the discharge.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 30, Page no 30.3

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine - 19th Edition Page no 1005

questions.text: A patient presents to you with multiple anogenital warts. The biopsy of these lesions showed squamous atypia. Which of the following HPV types are considered high risk?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HPV 18.

 

Option B:

HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
 

  • HPV 18 is considered a high-risk HPV type because it is associated with an increased risk of developing anogenital cancers, particularly cervical cancer.
  • High-risk HPV types can cause cellular changes that may progress to cancer if not treated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HPV 2:
 

  • This type of HPV is considered low-risk and is typically associated with common warts, not anogenital warts or cancers.

 

Option C. HPV 6:
 

  • HPV 6 is also a low-risk type, commonly associated with the development of genital warts, but not with high-grade squamous atypia or cancer.

 

Option D. HPV 11:
 

  • Like HPV 6, HPV 11 is known to cause genital warts, but it is not associated with high-grade squamous lesions or malignancy.


 

 

 

Note - Gardasil-9 Nonavalent Vaccine - HPV-6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52 & 58. Protects against 6 cancers (Cervix, Vulva, Vagina, Anal Canal, Penis & Oral Cancers))+ Genital warts. 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the context of anogenital warts, HPV 18 is categorized as a high-risk type because of its association with anogenital carcinomas, especially cervical cancer.
  • In contrast, HPV types 6 and 11 are low-risk types commonly associated with benign anogenital warts and do not typically lead to cancer.
  • HPV 2 is typically associated with common skin warts and not anogenital lesions.
  • It is crucial for healthcare professionals to distinguish between high-risk and low-risk HPV types to provide appropriate patient counselling and management.

questions.text: A college student came with painful grouped vesicles over genitalia. What will be next best investigation you want to perform and what could be the possible finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tzanck smear to detect Tzanck cells


Option D:

Tzanck smear to detect Tzanck cells.
 

  • The Tzanck smear is a test used to examine the cells from blistering skin conditions.
  • In the case of herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections, multinucleated giant cells and Tzanck cells, may be seen.
  • This test is quick and cost-effective, although not specific for HSV or VZV.

 

Some important findings on Tzanck smear are as follows:

 

 

The presence of acantholytic cells on a Tzanck smear, which is characterized by the loss of keratinocyte cell adhesion (acantholysis).

 

 

High power view of Tzanck cells. Note the perinuclear halo visible in the marked cell.

 

Image: Tzanck smear, showing multinucleated giant cells in center

 

 

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Tzanck_test.png
 

  • The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gram stain to detect Gram-positive organisms
 

  • The Gram stain is used to classify bacteria as either Gram-positive or Gram-negative.
  • This test is not appropriate for the clinical scenario described, as the presentation is not suggestive of a bacterial infection.

 

Option B. Skin biopsy to detect HP bodies
 

  • HP (Henderson-Patterson) bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in molluscum contagiosum, which is not consistent with the presentation of painful genital vesicles.
  • A skin biopsy is more invasive and not the first-line investigation in this scenario.

 

Option C. SSS to detect Acid-fast bacilli
 

  • An SSS (Slit Skin Smear) test for acid-fast bacilli is used in the diagnosis of leprosy, neither of which typically present as painful grouped vesicles in the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of painful grouped vesicles over the genitalia is most consistent with a herpes simplex virus infection, for which a Tzanck smear is a rapid diagnostic test that can demonstrate the presence of Tzanck cells, supporting the diagnosis.

 

Ref:

Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 418

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.21

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1404

questions.text: A commercial sex worker presents with an indurated, painless ulcer over her vulva. On examination painless inguinal lymphadenopathy is also present. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incubation period is 2-5 days.

 

Option B:

 

Incubation period is 2-5 days
 

  • With the clinical scenario given, the diagnosis would be Primary syphilis. Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • Treponema pallidum has corkscrew motility as seen below.

 

 

  • The incubation period of syphilis is 9-90 days and varies inversely with the size of the Spirochaete inoculum.
  • Extragenital syphilitic chancre can occur over fingers, hands, and the oral cavity.

 

Extragenital syphilitic chancre over Lips

 

 

  • The Dory flop sign is described in an uncircumcised male with an indurated lesion of primary syphilis on the underside of the coronal sulcus.
  • Here, prepucial retraction causes the foreskin to flip suddenly.
     

Prepucial chancre leading to Dory flop sign

 

Fig: Indurated ulcer (primary chancre) on the prepuce

 

  • The Dory flop sign can help distinguish chancres from other nonindurated causes of genital ulcer disease, such as Herpes simplex virus infection and chancroid.
  • It is named after the movement of a dory, a small wooden fishing boat, which flips suddenly when overturned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incubation period of syphilis is approximately 3 weeks to 3 months after exposure.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 29, Page no’s 29.7

questions.text: All of the following can be seen associated with Early congenital syphilis EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seventh nerve palsy

 

Option D. Seventh nerve palsy

 

  • Early congenital syphilis may present with vesiculobullous lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, and rhinitis.
  • Seventh nerve palsy is not typically a feature of early congenital syphilis but may be associated with late manifestations of the disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • Syphilitic rhinitis, commonly referred to as "snuffles," is frequently the first and most prevalent symptom of early congenital syphilis.
  • A profuse, serous nasal discharge with a significant amount of Treponema pallidum is how it presents.
  • Snuffles, Syphilitic pemphigus & Hepatosplenomegaly form the triad of Early Congenital syphilis.
  • Due to the destruction of the nose's bone and cartilage in later stages, a saddle nose may develop.
  • Congenital syphilis can spread intrapartum through lesions in the mother's genitalia or trans placentally from an infected mother. The primary and secondary stages of the disease are when the risk is greatest. It can result in fetal death or congenital syphilis in a live birth if untreated.
  • The onset of congenital syphilis can be early or late. Early disease manifests within two years, while late disease does so after three years.

 

Late congenital syphilis has Hutchinson's triad which includes the following:

 

1. Interstitial keratitis

2. Eighth nerve deafness

3. Hutchinson's teeth

 

Hutchinson teeth are abnormal permanent upper central incisors that are peg-shaped and notched.

 

 

  • Seventh nerve palsy is NOT a feature of early congenital syphilis.

 


 

  • It is associated with 8th nerve deafness, along with tinnitus and vertigo.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • Early congenital syphilis may present with vesiculobullous lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, and rhinitis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 29, Page nos 29.28-29

questions.text: After 14 hours of receiving Injection Penicillin for her early latent syphilis, a 35-year-old woman suddenly develops a high-grade fever, myalgia, and bone pain. Which of the following statements is FALSE with respect to her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Penicillin cannot be used in future

 

Option B: Penicillin cannot be used in future

 

  • The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a temporary reaction to antibiotic therapy for syphilis, characterized by fever, myalgia, and bone pain, and is not a contraindication to future penicillin use.

 

Explanation:

 

  • A febrile reaction occurring within 24 hours of penicillin therapy for syphilis is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer's reaction.
  • Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is self-limiting and is due to lipoprotein release from the dying treponemes, which trigger cytokine release.
  • The patient presents with flu-like symptoms and exacerbation of skin lesions. Fever rarely lasts more than 8 hours. Symptoms may be controlled by antipyretics. It is not a contraindication for penicillin use in the future.
  • Penicillin allergy is a contraindication for further use. JH reactions must be differentiated from penicillin allergy.
  • Constitutional Symptoms such as Fever, Joint Pain, Hypotension along with Worsening of Skin Lesions. Treatment : Symptomatic

 

Allergic reactions can be early or late as follows:

 

  • Early type- anaphylaxis within 1 hour of the first dose.
  • Late type- rash after several doses of penicillin.

 

In Jarisch-Herxheimer's reaction, Corticosteroids are only indicated in pregnant women and patients with neurosyphilis in whom the reaction can be more serious and life-threatening sequelae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a temporary reaction to antibiotic therapy for syphilis, characterized by fever, myalgia, and bone pain, and is not a contraindication to future penicillin use.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition

Chapter 29, Page nos 29.26

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 3167

questions.text: A 45-year-old truck driver with a history of multiple sex partners presented to the dermatological department, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secondary syphilis

 

Option A Secondary syphilis

 

  • The diagnosis of the image which is showing hyperpigmented macules, suggestive of palmoplantar syphillides is secondary syphilis
  • This is characterized by systemic manifestations, including a rash which may cover the entire body or be localized to the palms and soles, mucous patches, condylomata lata, and lymphadenopathy.
  • This stage reflects the hematogenous spread of Treponema pallidum.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lichen Planus

 

  • It presents pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques with fine scales.
  • Wickham striae, reticular white lines on the surface of the lesions, are characteristic.

 

Option C. Scabies

 

  • It is an intensely pruritic skin condition caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei, leading to burrows, erythematous papules, and excoriation, typically involving the web spaces of the fingers, wrists, and waistline.

 

Option D Psoriasis

 

  • This typically presents well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, often on extensor surfaces and the scalp. Nail changes and joint involvement can also occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary syphilis is identified by characteristic systemic rash, which often involves the palms and soles, and its association with a history of sexual contact, which can include multiple partners.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 270

questions.text: A man is referred to the STI clinic with the following painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. He gives a history of a small transient painless ulcer on his penis 5 weeks ago, which resolved on its own. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caused by Chlamydia Trachomatis Serovars D-K

 

Option B: Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars D-K

 

Explanation:

 

  • This image shows the pathognomonic groove sign of Greenblatt (Option C) which is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3.

  • In one-third of cases, a groove sign is visible. It describes the depression on either side of the inguinal ligament that is situated between the enlarged femoral and inguinal lymph nodes.

  • Following a painless genital ulcer, buboes, or painful masses of lymph nodes, can be seen. Usually, lymphogranuloma venereum exhibits this.

  • Incubation period is 3-30 days. There are three phases in it. (Option D)

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum:

Primary stage:

 

  • Starts with painless papules or transient ulcers that may go unnoticed at the inoculation site.

  • The conventional ulcer is solitary, shallow, unindurated, and may or may not be painful.

 

Secondary stage:

 

  • Appearance of tender femoral and/or inguinal lymphadenopathy develops 2–6 weeks later. Buboes or abscesses may develop from the nodes when they coalesce, and fistulae and sinus tracts may develop when they rupture. (Option A)


Tertiary stage:

 

  • Occurs several years later and is characterized by lymphatic obstruction and disfiguring conditions such as elephantiasis and Esthiomene.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, or L3, not serovars D-K, and presents with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy and may have a transient genital ulcer.

  • The groove sign is pathognomonic for LGV, and the incubation period ranges from 3 to 30 days.

 

Ref:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.18

questions.solution:
Ans. B) Red kit

 

Option B: Red kit

  • It is treated with a red kit. In herpetic genital ulcer disease, treatment of asymptomatic partners is not required.

  • Chancroid, which manifests as numerous, tender soft, painful ulcers, & bilateral lymphadenopathy is a close differential diagnosis.

  • Chancroid, on the other hand, lacks vesicles and has deeper ulcers with ragged, undermined edges.

  • Only when the patient presents with the primary chancre of syphilis is the patient's history of penicillin drug allergy relevant.

  • They would need to be treated with a blue kit in this situation rather than a white kit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The treatment of Genital Herpes involves antiviral therapy, which is typically provided in the red kit.

  • It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days, which is effective against the herpes simplex virus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old sexually active male presents to an STD clinic with painful genital sores as shown in the image below. He reports that the lesion appeared about two weeks ago and has been progressively worsening. On examination, you observe multiple painful bleeding ulcers with unilateral unilocular painful suppurative inguinal bubo. There are no other visible lesions, and the patient denies any systemic symptoms. He had multiple sexual partners in recent months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid (Soft chancre)

 

OPTION C:

 

Chancroid (Soft chancre):

 

  • Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It presents with painful genital ulcers and painful suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo), as described in the scenario.
  • The ulcers are often described as "soft" (as opposed to the "hard" chancre of syphilis) and can bleed easily.
  • This fits the patient's presentation perfectly.

 

Explanation:

 

OPTION A: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection:

 

  • HSV typically presents as painful vesicles that can rupture to form ulcers.
  • The key difference is that the inguinal lymphadenopathy seen in HSV (if present) is typically bilateral and not as dramatically painful or suppurative as that in chancroid.

 

Differentiating features between Herpes genitalis & Chancroid:
 

 

  • Moreover, the course of the lesion and the presence of multiple painful ulcers fit chancroid better than HSV.

 

OPTION B: Syphilis (Primary Stage):

 

  • The primary lesion of syphilis is the chancre, which is a solitary, painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders.
  • The patient's presentation of multiple painful ulcers with a painful inguinal bubo does not fit the primary syphilis picture.

 

OPTION D: Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale):

 

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, donovanosis typically presents as painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily. They can progress to cause destruction of genital tissue.
  • While there are similarities in the ulcer presentation between chancroid and donovanosis, the painful and suppurative inguinal bubo described in the case is more characteristic of chancroid.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a sexually active individual with painful genital sores, multiple painful bleeding ulcers, and a unilateral unilocular painful suppurative inguinal bubo, the most likely diagnosis is Chancroid.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.21

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with a chronic, pruritic rash composed of erythematous patches and plaques. Histological examination of a skin biopsy shows clusters of atypical lymphocytes within intraepidermal abscesses. What is this histopathological finding known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pautrier's microabscesses 

 

Option C:

 

• These are a diagnostic histopathological feature of mycosis fungoides, a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

• They consist of collections of atypical lymphocytes within the epidermis, often without any associated spongiosis

 

Explanation:

Option A) Munro's microabscesses

• These are collections of neutrophils within the stratum corneum and are typically found in psoriasis, not mycosis fungoides.

Option B) Spongiform Pustules of Kogoj

• These are also associated with psoriasis and represent a spongiform collection of neutrophils in the epidermis.

 

Option D) Papillary Tip Microabscesses

• These are typically seen in dermatitis herpetiformis and consist of neutrophils at the tips of dermal papillae, usually accompanied by granular deposits of IgA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pautrier's microabscesses are a hallmark histopathological feature of mycosis fungoides, which are characterized by clusters of atypical lymphocytes within the epidermis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition: page no 140.7

questions.text: The girl seen in the image has had history of severe sunburns after just a few minutes in the sun, she also has history of photosensitivity & severe freckling in the sun exposed areas. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xeroderma Pigmentosa.

 

Option B.

 

  • The image shows a girl with Xeroderma Pigmentosa. It is characterised by defective Nucleotide Excision Repair.
  • A rare autosomal recessive genetic condition called Xeroderma pigmentosa causes clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to UV radiation and other carcinogens as a result of faulty DNA repair.

 

Important clinical features are:

 

  • First Stage: Child is asymptomatic at birth. Diffuse erythema scaling & freckle like lesions over the sun exposed regions of the body at around 6 months of age.
  • Second Stage: Poikiloderma is a characteristic feature of the second stage of Xeroderma Pigmentosa.
  • Poikiloderma is a special skin lesion with a triad of features {ATP}
    • Atrophy of skin
    • Telangiectasia (Permanently dilated blood vessels)
    • Pigment abnormalities (Dyspigmentation, both hypo & hyper)
  • Poikiloderma may be congenital or acquired. It is associated with mycosis fungoides, dermatomyositis etc.

 

Third stage:

 

  • Increased incidence of Cutaneous malignancies like:
    • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
    • Malignant melanoma
    • Basal Cell Carcinoma
    • Fibrosarcoma.
  • The final diagnosis of Xeroderma Pigmentosa can be confirmed by special laboratory tests by the examining the DNA damage repair in cells from cultures exposed to UV radiation. The most common tests are skin biopsy & culture of skin fibroblasts.
  • There is no cure for Xeroderma Pigmentosa.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Minimise exposure to sunlight
  • Regular dermatological care,
  • Surgery for recurrent tumours excision.
  • Follow up every 3 months.
  • Genetic counselling is important in a family that has an affected child & is considering having more children.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Blooms Syndrome:

 

  • It is characterized by short stature, sun-sensitive skin lesions, and an increased risk of cancers, but the freckling noted in the clinical picture is more characteristic of XP.

 

Option C. Warts:

 

  • They are benign growths caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and do not have a relationship with sun exposure or photosensitivity.

 

Option D. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus):

  • Pityriasis alba is a common cause of hypopigmented lesions in children, which may be confused with other conditions such as vitiligo or indeterminate leprosy.

questions.text: Histopathology of a tissue sample from a patient with leprosy is shown below. All the following are possibilities EXCEPT.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculoid leprosy

 

Option A:

 

  • The given image shows a Grenz zone or Band of Unna, which is a band of uninvolved papillary dermis that does not contain granulomas or inflammatory infiltrate.
  • Grenz zone is absent in Tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Dermal granulomas, which are collections of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are seen in tuberculoid leprosy.
  • The granulomas are elongated and typically follow neurovascular bundles, running parallel to the surface. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lepromatous Leprosy –

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy represents the polar opposite of the leprosy spectrum with poor cell-mediated immunity leading to a multibacillary state.
  • Lepromatous leprosy exhibits the Grenz zone most obviously because there are not many granulomas to fill the empty spaces below the epidermis.
  • The Virchow cells with globi as indicated in the image, which are large macrophages filled with mycobacteria, are a characteristic feature of lepromatous leprosy.
  • Additionally, it appears on the borderline spectrum.

 

Option C. Borderline Leprosy –

 

  • Borderline leprosy falls within the middle of the leprosy spectrum, with histological features that can fluctuate between those seen in tuberculoid and lepromatous forms.
  • It can show a grenz zone and foamy macrophages, which makes it a possibility in this case.

 

Option D. Borderline Lepromatous leprosy –

 

  • Borderline Lepromatous leprosy is a subtype of leprosy that falls between the lepromatous and tuberculoid forms.
  • It would show features of both, with numerous bacteria present as well as some immune response limiting the spread.
  • Therefore, the histological findings seen in the image could correspond to this type, making it a possible option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The absence of a grenz zone in histopathological samples is associated with tuberculoid leprosy, while the presence of a grenz zone and Virchow cells with globi are indicative of lepromatous forms of the disease.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No. 28.5

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with multiple hypopigmented patches on back & lower limb. On examination the patches were hypo aesthetic & bilateral ulnar and lateral popliteal nerves were enlarged. Which of the following drugs and their dosages are to be given on Day 1 of supervised drug administration according to National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) Guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rifampicin 450 mg Clofazimine 150 mg Dapsone 50 mg

 

Option A.

 

Latest Guidelines for Leprosy: NLEP = WHO (from April 1, 2025)

As of April 1, 2025, India's NLEP has aligned completely with WHO guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of leprosy. This means that the same criteria and drug regimens are now followed globally and in India.

 

  • A 12-year-old child presenting with multiple hypopigmented and hypo aesthetic patches with bilateral ulnar and popliteal nerves enlarged clinches the diagnosis of Multi Bacillary Leprosy

  • Hence treatment would be with MB MDT regimen according to NLEP Guidelines

 

Explanation:

 

  • According to the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) Guidelines, for a child aged 9-14 years, the Day 1 supervised dose of medication for Multi-Bacillary (MB) leprosy includes Rifampicin 450 mg, Clofazimine 150 mg, and Dapsone 50 mg.

 

 

Option B. Rifampicin 600 mg Clofazimine 300 mg Dapsone 100 mg:

 

  • Incorrect because this dosage is for adults with MB leprosy, not for children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct dosages of multi-drug therapy for a child with Multi-Bacillary (MB) leprosy on Day 1 of supervised treatment according to NLEP Guidelines, which for a child aged 9-14 years includes Rifampicin 450 mg, Clofazimine 150 mg, and Dapsone 50 mg.

questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepromatous leprosy (LL)

 

Option B:

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy is characterized by numerous foam cells, also known as Virchow's cells, which are lipid-laden macrophages filled with Mycobacterium leprae.
     

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Borderline lepromatous (BL):

 

  • BL leprosy can have foam cells, they are most abundant in LL leprosy where there is widespread infiltration of the skin with numerous bacilli.

 

Option C. Pure Neuritic Leprosy:

 

  • Pure Neuritic Leprosy primarily affects nerves, and foam cells are more typically associated with cutaneous lesions.

 

Option D. Borderline (BB):

 

  • In BB leprosy, foam cells may be present but are not as prominent as in LL leprosy.
  • BB leprosy has features between tuberculoid and lepromatous leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy (LL) is the form of Hansen's disease most associated with the presence of abundant foam cells, which are macrophages filled with undigested M. leprae.
  • These foam cells are indicative of the multibacillary form of the disease and are used as a diagnostic histopathological feature.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE in relation to Type 2 Lepra Reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Underlying Pathogenesis is Increased Cell Mediated Immunity.

 

Option C:

 

  • The pathogenesis of Type 2 Lepra Reaction (ENL) is primarily due to immune complex deposition(Type III hypersensitivity reaction) and not increased cell-mediated immunity, which is more characteristic of Type 1 reactions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Seen in Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy and Lepromatous Leprosy patients:

 

  • Type 2 Lepra Reaction, also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), is typically seen in patients with Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy and Lepromatous Leprosy, which are at the multibacillary end of the leprosy spectrum.

 

Option B. MDT should be continued, and Steroids are to be added:

 

  • During a Type 2 reaction, the mainstay treatment includes the continuation of Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) for leprosy along with the addition of steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction.

 

Option D. Patients present with High grade fever, Red Tender nodules over body:

 

  • The clinical presentation of ENL includes systemic symptoms such as high-grade fever and red tender nodules, known as erythema nodosum leprosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type 2 Lepra Reaction (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum) is associated with immune complex deposition rather than increased cell-mediated immunity.
  • It presents with systemic symptoms and cutaneous manifestations requiring the continuation of MDT and the addition of anti-inflammatory treatment, typically steroids.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 29 Page No 424

questions.text: A farmer having trauma history in lower limb following which a cauliflower-like growth developed on that site. On HPE copper penny bodies are seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. chromoblastomycosis

 

Option A.

 

Chromoblastomycosis:

 

  • Caused by Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora species.
  • Clinical features : The lesions start as warty papules, slowly enlarge to form a cauliflower like hypertrophic plaque progressing to large Cauliflower like hyperkeratotic masses over months to years, surface often studded with black dots .
  • Histopathology: Foreign body granuloma & Sclerotic / Medlar / Copper penny  /Muriform bodies

 

Treatment: Itraconazole.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. While mycetoma can also present as a growth on the site of trauma, it is differentiated by the presence of draining sinuses with granules and does not typically show copper penny bodies on HPE.

 

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis

 

  • It is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii, commonly presenting as nodular lesions along lymphatic channels.

 

 

  • It does not show copper penny bodies but rather asteroid bodies in tissue.

 

Option D. Phaeohyphomycosis

 

  • This describes a group of infections caused by dematiaceous (darkly pigmented) fungi.
  • While it can present with various clinical manifestations, copper penny bodies are not a characteristic finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The identification of copper penny bodies on histopathology is indicative of Chromoblastomycosis, a fungal infection that leads to characteristic verrucous skin lesions.
  • This finding, along with the clinical history of a cauliflower-like growth following trauma in a farmer, solidifies the diagnosis and guides appropriate antifungal therapy.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.76

questions.text: A farmer comes to skin OPD with a painful, swollen foot which has discharging sinuses & dark grains coming out of sinuses. Diagnosis of this case scenario would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Eumycetoma

 

Option B.

 

The diagnosis with the given case scenario would be Eumycetoma (Madura foot)

 

 

Clinical features: (GST)

 

  1. Grains,
  2. Sinuses,
  3. Tumefaction/sweling

 

The below image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge.

 

 

Treatment:

 

  1. Eumycetoma:
  • Antifungals (Itraconazole)
  1. Actinomycetoma:
  • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
  • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin
     

Explanation:

 

Option A. Botryomycosis:

 

  • It is a chronic bacterial infection that typically presents with granulomatous lesions but is not known for producing dark grains as described.

 

Option C. Actinomycetoma:

 

  • It is caused by filamentous bacteria, not fungi, and typically produces lighter-colored grains in discharging sinuses.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis:

 

  • It usually presents as a nodular lymphangitis, with lesions along the lymphatic channels rather than the presentation of a swollen foot with discharging sinuses and dark grains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Eumycetoma is diagnosed by the presence of characteristic dark granules in discharges from sinuses on the affected area.
  • These grains are aggregates of the causative fungi, such as Madurella mycetomatis, and differentiate eumycetoma from actinomycetoma, which is caused by filamentous bacteria and typically presents with paler granules.
  • Treatment involves long-term antifungal therapy and sometimes surgery.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mycetoma

 

Option A.

 

  • Clinical image depicts swollen foot and multiple sinuses, which in the context of farmer, is consistent with a diagnosis of Mycetoma.

 

Mycetoma:

 

  • It is a chronic granulomatous infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, which can extend to the underlying bone.
  • It typically presents in farmers or individuals who walk barefoot in endemic areas, with swollen feet and multiple sinuses that may discharge grains.

 

 

Option B. A Rodent ulcer

 

  • It is more commonly known as a basal cell carcinoma, typically presents as a skin lesion that may ulcerate but does not produce sinus tracts and granules.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis

 

  • This is a fungal infection that typically presents as nodular lesions along lymphatic drainage, not typically with multiple sinuses and granules.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)

 

  • This may present as a non-healing ulcer or nodule in sun-exposed areas but would not typically present with multiple draining sinuses and granules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct diagnosis of mycetoma is based on the presentation of a swollen foot with multiple sinuses and granules, often associated with an occupational history of exposure to soil.
  • Recognizing this presentation is important for the management and initiation of appropriate antimicrobial therapy.Top of FormBottom of Form

Ans. D. Cryotherapy is a painless procedure

 

Option D.

 

The main disadvantage of Cryotherapy / Freezing is pain.

 

Cryogun has the freezing agent:

 

 

Below image depicts Cryotherapy being administered:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by human papillomavirus-2 (HPV-2) but is also related to types 1, 4, 27, and 57.

 

Below image depicts Verruca vulgaris:

 

 

  • Common warts typically have no symptoms.
  • They appear as firm papules with a rough horny surface and exhibit acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and papillomatosis.
  • The hands, fingers, and knees of young children are the areas that are most frequently affected.
  • Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed.

 

Option B: Deep palmoplantar warts are also called Myrmecia warts.

 

  • It is usually caused by human papillomavirus-1 (HPV-1).
  • The superficial form of plantar warts is called mosaic warts which are caused by HPV-2.

 

Below image depicts Plantar warts

 

 

Various types of warts and their clinical features:

 

  • Verrucous warts present as asymptomatic skin-coloured papules and plaques with rough surfaces.
  • Filiform warts are finger-like projections.

 

 

  • Verruca Plana are flat surfaced lesions and hence the name. They are mainly due to HPV-3 and - 10.

 

 

Option C: Anogenital Warts are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6 > HPV-11).

 

 

Educational Objective: 

Cryotherapy:

 

  • A doctor administers this treatment.
  • Liquid nitrogen, carbon dioxide snow, and dimethyl ether can all cause thermal injury to the skin.
  • The coldest freeze is produced by liquid nitrogen, which is frequently employed in practice.
  • A cotton wool bud or a cryospray is used to apply it until a rim of iced tissue forms around the wart (visible as a white discoloration).
  • Depending on the size and location of the wart, the freezing is maintained for 5 to 30 seconds.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents to the clinic with several fluid-filled blisters on the skin and some areas with a varnish-coloured crust. The infant does not appear to be in significant discomfort, and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Given the clinical presentation and the age of the infant, which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Golden yellow- or honey-coloured crusts are seen associated with this disease

The clinical picture described—a 2-month-old infant with fluid-filled blisters and varnish coloured crusts—is classic for bullous impetigo, a localized superficial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The exfoliative toxins released by the bacteria specifically target desmoglein-1 of the epidermis. This results in the formation of superficial intraepidermal bullae that rupture easily, leaving a varnish-like crust, rather than the golden yellow or honey-coloured crusts that are seen in non-bullous impetigo.

Other options:

  • A. Bullous impetigo is the other name for this disease:
    This is a true and appropriate statement. The condition described aligns with the presentation of bullous impetigo, and it is correctly named as such.
  • B. Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism:
    Accurate. The organism Staphylococcus aureus is responsible for bullous impetigo, owing to its production of exfoliative toxins.

  • D. Superficial intraepidermal bulla are formed as desmoglein-1 is targeted by the exfoliative toxins:
    This is a correct pathophysiological mechanism explaining how the bullae form in this condition. 

     

Pemphigus neonatorum / Bullous impetigo:

 

  • It is the most likely diagnosis from the given clinical case scenario.

  • It is caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Impetigo is a contagious, superficial pyogenic infection of the skin.

  • Superficial intraepidermal bulla are formed as desmoglein-1 is targeted by the exfoliative toxins produced by S. aureus.

  • After the bulla rupture, they leave behind varnish crust (NOT Golden yellow or honey-coloured crusts).

  • Below image depicts Bullous Impetigo with intact bullae & Varnish coloured crusts.

  • Hypopyon Sign - The pus gravitates to the lower half of the bulla. 

 

 

Complication:

 

Hematogenous spread of Exfoliative toxin can lead to Ritter's disease/Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS).

 

Impetigo management:

 

  • Treatment involves topical Fucidin or mupirocin, retapamulin in resistant cases.

  • Systemic therapy with flucloxacillin and erythromycin may be given.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus neonatorum, or bullous impetigo, typically presents with varnish-like crusts rather than golden yellow or honey-colored crusts after bullae rupture.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition

Chapter 26, Page nos 26.14-26.15

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the clinic with complaints of fever, irritability, poor oral intake, and skin lesions. Vitals examination revealed increased Heart rate (tachycardia present) and a temperature of 101 F. On examination of the skin, diffuse erythema is present along with flaccid bullae. The skin is moist, erythematous, and shiny. Some areas of the skin are desquamated, as shown in the image below. The culture from the lesions is positive for Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Scalded Skin Syndrome

 

Option D.

 

Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS)

 

  • It is a condition caused by the exotoxins of Staphylococcus aureus, which can lead to the widespread formation of flaccid bullae that rupture easily, causing desquamation and erythematous, shiny skin underneath.
  • This clinical picture is consistent with the findings in the patient described: fever, irritability, poor oral intake, diffuse erythema, flaccid bullae, and positive culture for Staphylococcus aureus.
  • SSSS is particularly common in young children and infants.
  • Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis is an important differential if adults are having similar clinical features.
  • Differences between Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis and SSSS are given in the table below.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Congenital syphilis

 

  • It presents with various signs including snuffles, vesiculobullous rash, Hepatosplenomegaly, Hutchinson teeth and bony abnormalities.
  • Positive bacterial culture makes SSSS more likely diagnosis, though vesiculobullous lesions can be seen in both these conditions.

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • It is an autoimmune disease that presents with flaccid bullae and erosions, but it is extremely rare in children and does not typically present with systemic symptoms such as fever or a positive bacterial culture.

 

Option C. Epidermolysis bullosa

 

  • It is a group of genetic disorders that present with blistering of the skin and mucous membranes in response to minor trauma since birth.
  • It would not cause fever, systemic symptoms, or a positive bacterial culture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) based on the clinical presentation of fever, irritability, poor oral intake, diffuse erythema, flaccid bullae, shiny erythematous skin, desquamation, and a positive Staphylococcus aureus culture, especially in the paediatric population.Top of Form

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presented with well demarcated redness over leg as shown in the image below. It was extremely painful. Which of the following statement is true regarding it?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It feels hard on palpation.

 

Option C.

 

  • Erysipelas is characterized by well-demarcated redness and warmth, and it often feels firm or raised on palpation due to the inflammatory response.
  • Therefore, this statement is true.
  • Clinical image shows well defined erythematous plaques over leg.
  • Differential diagnosis of tender erythematous plaques over leg are erysipelas and cellulitis.
  • Erysipelas is a skin infection that typically presents with well-demarcated redness, warmth, and pain, most commonly affecting the lower extremities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Can be caused by both Staphylococcus and Streptococcus:

 

  • Erysipelas is caused by Streptococcus, especially Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes).
  • Staphylococcus is not a causative agent for erysipelas.
  • Therefore, this statement is not true.

 

Option B. It extends deep into subcutaneous tissues:

 

  • Erysipelas typically involves the upper layers of the skin and the superficial dermis but does not extend deep into subcutaneous tissues.
  • It is more superficial compared to cellulitis.
  • Therefore, this statement is not true.

 

 

Option D. It never involves the ear:

 

  • Erysipelas can affect various parts of the body, including the ear (Milian's Ear Sign).
  • Ear involvement is called Milian's ear sign, and it is a feature distinguishing erysipelas from cellulitis, because the pinna has no deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissue .

 

 

  • It is not restricted to any specific anatomical location.
  • Therefore, this statement is not true.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, primarily caused by Streptococcus, and is characterized by well-demarcated, painful, warm, and often firm or raised skin lesions.
  • It can affect various parts of the body, including the ear.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.19

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with red, subcutaneous violaceous swelling over the cervical region from the last several months. Some of the lesions ulcerated & underwent spontaneous healing leaving typical cord like scars. Infection of the underlying cervical lymph node is present with multiple sinuses. Histology showed marked caseous necrosis. Labs revealed CD4 count< 50 cells/mm3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scrofuloderma

 

Option A: The given image shows subcutaneous swelling over cervical lymph node region which are forming sinuses & healing with cord like scars, all these are classical features of Scrofuloderma. It is a multibacillary manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

  • It is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis in children. However, it can still be seen in adults, so the age group mentioned in the MCQ as adults does not change the answer here. (Lupus vulgaris is the most common type in adults.)

  • It results from contiguous spread to the skin from an underlying tuberculous focus.

  • This focus could usually be a lymph gland, an infected bone or joint, or a lacrimal gland or duct.

 

Scrofuloderma: Progression of the lesions is as follows:

 

  • Begins as subcutaneous swellings that are bluish-red and asymptomatic, and this stage lasts for months.

  • These subcutaneous swellings, degenerates into undermined ulcers.

  • In ulcers, granulation tissue proliferation results in fungating masses.

  • Several fistulae may develop and cause sinuses to drain onto the skin.

 

Histology reveals pronounced caseating necrosis, which typically contains lots of bacteria.

Although spontaneous healing is possible, the process takes a very long time and results in the typical, cord-like scars.

 

Antituberculosis therapy should be commenced promptly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lupus vulgaris:

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of cutaneous tuberculosis with apple jelly nodules, typically not associated with deep nodules, ulceration, or sinus tracts as in this case.

 

Option C. Acne vulgaris:

 

  • Acne vulgaris is a common skin condition characterized by comedones, papules, and pustules, not by ulceration or sinus tract formation, and is not associated with caseous necrosis or immunocompromised states.

 

Option D. Erythema nodosum:

 

  • Erythema nodosum presents as tender red nodules, typically on the lower legs, and does not lead to ulceration or sinus tract formation. It is also not associated with caseous necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of red, subcutaneous violaceous swelling that ulcerates and heals with scarring, coupled with infected cervical lymph nodes and sinus tract formation, in an immunocompromised patient with a low CD4 count and histology showing caseous necrosis, is indicative of scrofuloderma, a cutaneous form of tuberculosis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.13

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about tuberculosis verrucosa cutis EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post Primary Tuberculosis with poor immunity

 

Explanation:

 

Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis—

 

  • Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis (TBVC, also known as prosecutor’s Wart, Anatomist's Wart (OptionA), Verruca Necrogenica, and Warty Tuberculosis) is a form of Cutaneous TB that occurs after direct inoculation of the mycobacteria into the skin of a previously sensitized host with good immunity against the bacillus. (OptionB)
  • Inoculation typically occurs from an exogenous source.
  • In adults, TBVC most frequently develops on the Acral Extremities; the Fingers and Dorsum of the hands are commonly affected. The Ankles or Buttocks are frequent sites for lesion occurrence in children.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • The skin lesions are usually solitary and manifest as painless, violaceous, or brown, red, indurated warty plaques that range from 1 to 5 cm in diameter. TBVC grows via peripheral extension.

 

Histopathology:

 

  • Due to the strong immune response, the lesion is paucibacillary (OptionC).
  • Histology shows hyperkeratosis with no granulomas.

 

Treatment:

 

  • The treatment of cutaneous TB is the same as that for systemic TB.
  • Antitubercular therapy is used in the management (OptionD)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis, also known as Anatomist's Wart is a paucibacillary cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in individuals with a good or moderate level of immunity and is managed with Antitubercular Therapy.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.19

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a chronic, progressive skin lesion on her buttock. On physical examination, a well-demarcated, erythematous plaque with deep-seated nodules is noted which was progressing at one end and becoming atrophied at the other end as shown in the image below. Diascopy of the nodules reveals an "apple jelly" color. The patient has a history of a positive tuberculin skin test but no history of active tuberculosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lupus Vulgaris

 

Option A:

 

  • This diagnosis correlates with the clinical features described in the vignette, including the chronicity of the lesion, the presentation of well-demarcated plaques progressing at one end and becoming atrophied at the other end with apple jelly nodules on diascopy, and the patient's history of a positive tuberculin skin test.

 

 

Above image depicts Apple Jelly Nodules

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitized individuals with moderate immunity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It presents with well-demarcated plaques that can have apple jelly nodules on diascopy.
  • This is consistent with the patient's presentation and history of a positive tuberculin skin test, making it the most likely diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Psoriasis

 

  • This typically presents as well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, most commonly on extensor surfaces, and scalp.

 

 

  • It is associated with systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis and does not produce apple jelly nodules on diascopy.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis

 

  • It is a multisystem granulomatous disorder that can present with skin manifestations known as lupus pernio, which can appear similar to lupus vulgaris but is associated with systemic symptoms such as dyspnea, cough, and ocular involvement.

 

 

  • It can present with apple jelly nodules on diascopy, but rest of the features which are in favor of Lupus vulgaris help us to rule out this option.

 

Option D. Granuloma Aannulare

 

  • This is a benign, self-limited dermatological condition that presents with annular plaques which are Non itchy and lack any scaling, presenttypically over joints and is not associated with the apple jelly nodules seen in cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical features of Lupus Vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, including the well-demarcated plaque, deep-seated nodules, and the characteristic "Apple Jelly" Colour on diascopy.
  • Understand the association with a positive tuberculin skin test and the chronic, progressive nature of the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE about Scabies?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivermectin is an Oral Medication used in the Treatment.

 

Option. C: Ivermectin is the only oral medication that can be used in the treatment of scabies.

 

Topical Formulations:

 

  • 5% Permethrin
  • Gamma Benzene Hexachloride
  • Lindane
  • Crotamiton

 

  • Many parasites, including mites, have neurotransmission induced by gamma amino butyric acid that is disrupted by oral ivermectin.
  • Patients over the age of two and weighing more than 15 kg receive a single 200 mcg/kg dose.
  • A second dose is required 7–14 days later because the medication has no ovicidal effect.
  • Invertebrate nerve synapses that use glutamate or gamma aminobutyric acid GABA are blocked by oral ivermectin, which causes the mite to become paralysed and die.
  • It is not indicated in infants & pregnant women
  • To prevent reinfection, this condition needs to be treated simultaneously in all family members, even those who are asymptomatic, and the clothing needs to be disinfected at the same time.
  • It manifests as a few violaceous, itchy nodules that are frequently found on the male genitalia, groin & axillae.
  • They signify an inflammatory response to mite antigens. After anti-scabies treatment, these nodules continue to grow for weeks or months.

 

The below image shows nodular scabies.

 

 

 

 

Explanation:  

 

Option A: The number of lesions does not correspond to the number of mites.

 

Option B: Topical 5% permethrin (NOT 50%) is used in the treatment of scabies.

 

Option D: An unusual scabies manifestation is nodular scabies. It is extremely itchy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivermectin is an oral medication used in scabies treatment.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 Page No 34.40 & 34.42

Lepromatous Leprosy

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with Normo-Anesthetic Hypopigmented Lesions and a History of Prolonged Fever in Childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the Absence of Thickened Nerves?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis.

 

Option D.

 

  • The case scenario suggests a diagnosis of Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis.

 

Post- Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis:

 

  • Occurs 1-5 years after Kala azar in untreated or incompletely treated cases. Manifests as nodules over exposed areas (Face), Hypopigmented macules over trunk and photosensitivity.

  • The rash is progressive over many years and seldom heals spontaneously.

 

 

Important differential for PKDL is Lepromatous leprosy:

 

 

 

Drug of choice for:

 

  • Kala azar - Liposomal Amphotericin B

  • PKDL - Miltefosine

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tuberculoid leprosy:

 

  • This form of leprosy presents with hypopigmented patches with well-defined borders.

  • However, it is typically associated with thickened nerves, which is absent in the patient described.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy:

 

  • This is a more advanced and disseminated form of leprosy with multiple nodules, plaques, and thickened nerves.

  • It doesn't fit the presentation described.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • It is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.

  • The initial presentation can be patches, which might resemble the described lesions, but the history of prolonged fever in childhood and the geographic location (Bihar) make PKDL more probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PKDL is a probable diagnosis in a patient with a history of prolonged fever in childhood presenting with normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesions without any thickened nerves, especially from the Bihar region.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 33.50-33.51, 140.10

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT match related to types of icthyosis & their characteristic features among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collodion membrane- Icthyosis Vulgaris

 

Option D.

 

  • Ichthyosis Vulgaris does not present with Collodion Membrane at Birth and is therefore a Wrong Match
  • Salient features of important Ichthyoses.

 

 

 

Collodion membrane:

 

  • Neonate encased in a shiny, Parchment-like Membrane (Collodion Baby), suggestive of disorder belonging to the Autosomal Recessive Congenital Ichthyosis (ARCI) spectrum.
  • Below image depicts, ARCI, in which shedding of collodion membranes is seen after 1 week.

 

 

  • The membrane usually peels off within the first 4 weeks of life.
  • Initially, the clinical presentation can be quite severe and often includes ectropion and everted lips of different degrees. This later clear.

 

Option B: Lamellar icthyosis

 

  • Eclabium & Ectropion in Lamellar icthyosis are seen in the below image:

 

 

All Collodion babies look alike at birth, but later take different clinical course, such as:

 

  • Lamellar Ichthyosis: after the collodion membrane sheds, the trunk and scalp develop large, dark gray to brownish scales, sparing the face and extremities.
  • Bathing Suit Ichthyosis: a lamellar form of the disease that spares the face and extremities and is distributed in a bathing suit pattern.
  • Self-Healing Collodion Baby.
  • Congenital Icthyosiform Erythroderma.
  • Acral Self-Healing Collodion Baby

 

Option C: Harlequin Icthyosis:

 

Harlequin Icthyosis

 

  • The most severe form of autosomal recessive congenital icthyosis is called harlequin icthyosis.
  • The ABCA12 genes mutations are seen. (option C)
  • Nearly the entire body has thickened skin at birth. Neonatal skin resembles armor at birth. Deep cracks separate the large, armor like plates that make up the skin.

 

Below image depicts a neonate with Harlequin icthyosis presenting with Armor like plates,

 

Eclabium & Ectropion.

 

 

  • Early in life, supportive care is usually needed continuously. Treatment options include retinoids, antibiotics, etretinate, and moisturizing cream.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A collodion membrane at birth is associated with lamellar ichthyosis, part of the group of autosomal recessive congenital ichthyoses, and not with ichthyosis vulgaris.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Page no. 65.4 to 65.10

Tuberous sclerosis
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
Systemic Sclerosis

questions.text: A young girl having low intelligence presented as shown below. There is history of epilepsy. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberous Sclerosis

 

Option B.

 

  • The image shows Angiofibroma’s, and in the background of low intelligence and Epilepsy history.
  • It points to the diagnosis of tuberous sclerosis (TS) / Epiloia (Epilepsy Low intelligence & Angiofibroma / Adenoma sebaceum).
  • Other cutaneous features of tuberous sclerosis:
    • Angiofibroma / Adenoma sebaceum: Firm, distinct, reddish-brown, telangiectatic papules with a diameter of 1 to 10 mm that enlarge during puberty but then remain unchanged.
    • They sometimes appear in the ears and extend from the nasolabial furrows to the cheeks and chin.

 

 

  • Shagreen Patch: A soft, skin-coloured plaque that is irregularly thickened, slightly elevated, and typically found in the lumbosacral region.

 

 

  • Ash-leaf macules:
    • They are typically found on the trunk or limbs and are white, ovoid or ash-leaf shaped, measuring 1-3 cm in length.
    • They are most easily seen when examined under Wood's light.
    • They are an important physical indicator because they can appear at birth or in the first few months of life, several years before other symptoms of the disease manifest.

 

 

  • Periungual fibroma / Koenen’s tumour: They appear at or after puberty as smooth, firm, flesh-colored excrescences emerging from the nail folds.

 

 

  • Firm fibromatous plaques, particularly on the forehead and scalp, soft pedunculated fibromas around the neck and axillae, and polio are some other cutaneous manifestations.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Neurofibromatosis typically presents with café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and Lisch nodules, not the facial angiofibromas seen in the image, which are commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is an autoimmune condition characterized by a broad spectrum of clinical presentations including malar rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, and systemic involvement, but not the specific facial lesions shown in the image.

 

Option D. Systemic Sclerosis:

 

  • Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with skin thickening, fibrosis, and in some cases, telangiectasia, but not with the facial angiofibromas and neurological symptoms seen in tuberous sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical triad of Facial Angiofibromas, Epilepsy, and Cognitive Impairment is indicative of Tuberous Sclerosis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 80, Page Nos 80.10-80.11

questions.text: A patient presents with the Tense bullous lesions associated with itching. Histopathology revealed Subepidermal blistering. What is the diagnosis of this condition & what are the antigens against which autoantibodies are most commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous Pemphigoid & BP180

 

Option A.

 

  • Bullous pemphigoid is a subepidermal vesiculobullous disorder where there is at the dermo-epidermal junction (DEJ).
  • Tense bullae which are associated with itching are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. The bullae are Nikolsky negative as acantholysis is absent.
  • Autoantibodies against BP180 are most commonly seen in this condition.

 

BP180 is also known as BPAg2, and it is seen in 75-90% of bullous pemphigoid patients. Autoantibodies against BP230or BPAg1 are recognized in 50-70% of bullous pemphigoid patients.

 

 

Histopathology of Bullous Pemphigoid showing Subepidermal split:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris & Desmoglein 3.

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is associated with flaccid blisters, not tense ones, and the blisters are intraepidermal due to acantholysis.
  • The main autoantigen is Desmoglein 3, a desmosomal protein.

 

Option C. Bullous Pemphigoid & BP280.

 

  • This option is incorrect because BP280 (collagen type VII) is not the primary

antigen in Bullous Pemphigoid; BP180 is the correct antigen.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris & Desmoglein 1.

 

  • While Desmoglein 1 is indeed a target antigen in some cases of Pemphigus vulgaris (usually in combination with Desmoglein 3), the description provided does not match Pemphigus vulgaris, which presents with supra basal intra-epidermal blistering and flaccid bullae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with tense bullae and histopathology showing subepidermal blistering, the diagnosis is Bullous Pemphigoid, and the autoantibodies are most commonly directed against the BP180 antigen.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page No 50.10

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl child presents to OPD with blisters over perioral area & other periorificial areas which are arranged annularly giving a ‘crown of jewels’ appearance (Image given below). Direct immunofluorescence microscopy revealed linear IgA deposition in Basement membrane zone. What is the most likely diagnosis & what is the drug of choice in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood & Dapsone

 

Option C.

 

  • The given image showing blisters over perioral area & other periorificial areas in an annular fashion giving a ‘crown of jewels’ appearance with linear deposition of IgA at the dermo-epidermal junction is diagnostic for linear IgA disease (LABD) or chronic bullous disorder of childhood (CBDC) or IgA pemphigoid.

 

 

  • It is the most common immunobullous disease in infants and children.
  • It has Bimodal age group distribution, i.e., it may occur <5 years or at 60-65 years of age.
  • It occurs in genetically susceptible individuals and can be triggered by drugs like vancomycin, penicillin, and NSAIDs.

 

Management:

 

  • While dapsone is primarily a bactericidal drug, it also has an anti-inflammatory action by decreasing the action of neutrophil enzymes. Hence, it is useful in the treatment of IgA pemphigoid.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid

 

  • It is typically a disease of the elderly and is characterized by subepidermal blisters with linear IgG and C3 deposition, not IgA.
  • Dapsone is not the first-line treatment for bullous pemphigoid.

 

Option B. Chronic bullous disease of childhood (CBDC), also known as linear IgA disease.

 

  • It is the correct diagnosis based on the description, but azathioprine is not the drug of choice.
  • It is used as a second-line or adjunctive therapy when dapsone is contraindicated or insufficient.

 

Option D. Epidermolysis bullosa simplex

 

  • It is a hereditary condition characterized by skin fragility and blistering due to cytoskeletal protein mutations.
  • Genetic counselling may be of value for familial planning, but the condition does not present with linear IgA deposition, nor is it treated with dapsone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a child presenting with annularly arranged periorificial blisters and linear IgA deposition at the basement membrane zone, the most likely diagnosis is Chronic bullous disease of childhood, and the drug of choice is dapsone.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page N50.33

questions.text: A 30-year-old female in her third trimester of pregnancy presents to the dermatology clinic with a 2-week history of itchy, tense blisters centralized on her abdomen, especially around the umbilical area. The blisters are on an erythematous base and she denies any prior history of similar lesions. She has no significant medical history and her pregnancy has been uneventful until these skin changes. Examination does not reveal involvement of the mucous membranes. Based on the clinical presentation, the most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigoid Gestationis

 

Option D.

 

Pemphigoid gestationis / Gestational pemphigoid / Herpes gestationis

 

  • This autoimmune blistering disorder occurs during pregnancy, typically in the second or third trimester, and is characterized by pruritic, tense blisters on the abdomen, often starting near the umbilicus.

 

 

  • It is associated with antibodies to BP180 and BP230, similar to bullous pemphigoid but is pregnancy specific.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bullous pemphigoid:

 

  • Incorrect because it typically affects older individuals and is not associated with pregnancy.

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • Incorrect because this condition presents with grouped vesicles and intense pruritus, often on extensor surfaces, and is associated with celiac disease.

 

Option C. PUPPP (Pruritic Urticarial Papules and Plaques of Pregnancy):

 

  • Incorrect because PUPPP usually presents with urticarial papules and plaques, starts in the stretch marks of the abdomen, and typically does not involve the formation of blisters.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigoid gestationis is a pruritic, vesiculobullous disorder of pregnancy presenting with tense blisters around the umbilical area, typically occurring in the second or third trimester, without mucosal involvement.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 115.13

Tzanck cells are keratinocytes
Acantholytic cells are seen in Pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: All of the following are correct about Tzanck smear findings EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is the most accurate test for pemphigus vulgaris

 

Option D.

 

  • Direct Immunofluorescence Microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test for Pemphigus vulgaris, NOT Tzanck smear.
  • This clinical picture is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. The first line investigation is Tzanck smear.
  • It allows us to visualize the histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any Romanowsky stain.
  • Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy.
  • Direct immunofluorescence microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear are seen in varicella-zoster and herpes simplex infections.

 

  • The Frenchman Tzanck invented the Tzanck smear, a cheap, easy-to-use bedside cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular, and bullous diseases, particularly herpes.
  • Several techniques can be used to stain Tzanck smears, but Giemsa stain is the most popular.
  • Haematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou, and toluidine blue are additional stains that are employed.
  • Results in Tzanck Smear:

 

Option B: Tzanck cells / Acantholytic cells are Keratinocytes

 

  • They are seen in vesiculobullous disorders, as a result of acantholysis.
  • The keratinocytes lose their polyhedral shapes and characteristically become round with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and an abundance of basophilic cytoplasm.
  • Due to the cytoplasm's propensity to condense at the cell's periphery and create a perinuclear halo, the basophilic staining is more pronounced peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells).

 

Option C:

 

Some important findings on Tzanck smear are as follows:

 

 

Image: Tzanck smear, showing multinucleated giant cells in center

 

 

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Tzanck_test.png

 

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Tzanck smear can show multinucleated giant cells in varicella-zoster infections and acantholytic cells in Pemphigus vulgaris, but it is not the most accurate test for Pemphigus vulgaris; that distinction belongs to direct immunofluorescence.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 3.25, 50.4-50.8

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of a progressive rash that started on her face and has now spread to her chest and scalp over the last 3 months. She reports that the lesions began as small blisters that broke easily, leaving behind crusted, scaly areas and shallow erosions. She denies any mucosal involvement or recent illnesses. She is otherwise healthy and takes no regular medications. On physical examination, you note several superficial erosions with crusts on the scalp and chest. There are no intact blisters, and no lesions are found in the oral cavity. A skin biopsy is taken from the edge of an eroded lesion on the chest. Based on the clinical presentation, what will most likely be observed in the histopathology of the skin biopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subcorneal Acantholytic Blister

 

Option A.

 

Pemphigus Foliaceus (PF)

 

  • The patient's presentation is suggestive of Pemphigus foliaceus, which is a less severe variant of Pemphigus that typically affects the skin but spares the mucosa.
  • It is characterized by superficial blisters that rupture easily, leading to scaly, crusted lesions as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The histopathology of Pemphigus foliaceus typically shows subcorneal blisters with acantholysis, which is the separation of keratinocytes due to the presence of autoantibodies against desmoglein 1, a desmosomal protein.

 

 

  • Histopathological image of Pemphigus foliaceus (PF) showing subcorneal cleft.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Subcorneal non-acantholytic blister –

 

  • This would suggest a blistering process without cell-cell detachment, which is not consistent with Pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Option C. Subepidermal acantholytic blister –

 

  • This describes a blister beneath the entire epidermis with cell-cell detachment, which is not characteristic of Pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Option D. Subepidermal non-acantholytic blister –

 

  • This would suggest a blister beneath the epidermis without acantholysis, which is seen in conditions like Bullous pemphigoid, not Pemphigus foliaceus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus foliaceus in patients presenting with superficial, crusted, scaly lesions and shallow erosions on the skin, with histopathology revealing subcorneal acantholytic blisters.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 50.5

questions.text: The Below-Given Image is characteristically seen in which of the following type of Leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Borderline Leprosy (BB Leprosy)

 

Option C:

 

  • The given image shows a case of borderline leprosy, or dimorphous leprosy, as evidenced by the inverted saucer shaped cutaneous lesions on the patient's skin.
  • Inverted saucer shaped cutaneous lesions can also be seen in Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy (BL).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Borderline Tuberculoid Leprosy

 

  • It is characterized by fewer and more well-demarcated lesions than borderline leprosy, and there is a finding called as Satellite lesions which can be seen in BT leprosy.

 

Option B. Lepromatous leprosy

 

  • It presents with numerous lesions that are more symmetrical and have less sensory loss; it represents one polar end of the leprosy spectrum with a high bacterial load.

 

Option D. Histoid leprosy

 

  • It is a rare form of lepromatous leprosy presenting with firm, nodular lesions that typically do not resemble the "inverted saucer" appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of borderline leprosy (BB Leprosy) and distinguish it from other forms of leprosy.
  • It highlights the importance of recognizing the characteristic "inverted saucer" appearance of the cutaneous lesions and understanding the spectrum of leprosy classifications, which is essential for appropriate diagnosis and management

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No 28.3, 28.5, 28.10
